GEORGE MOLYNEUX . I am shopman to a pawnbroker—I produce this pick-axe, which was pawned on the 24th Dec.—I cannot say by whom—this is the duplicate I gave.
NOT GUILTY .

639.
JOHN HERITAGE and
JOSEPH JONES, alias Richard Boxall
, were indicted for
stealing 5 live tame fowls, price 1l. 10s.; the property of
John Vaughan: and
JOHN LAMBERT
for feloniously receiving 1 tame fowl, part of the same, knowing it to be stolen; and that Jones had been before convicted of felony.

JONES* pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

JAMES KENDALL . I am groom to Mr. John Vaughan—he lives at Old Peckham—my master had nine fowls, which were in my care—I saw then safe at five o'clock in the evening of the 23rd Jan.—the next morning five were missing—I afterwards saw four of them.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Did you count them when you saw them at five o'clock? A. Yes—they were my master's—they were there when I entered the service nine months ago—this is the leg of one of them I know it by a wort on it.

RICHARD HAMBROOK (police-constable P 109.) On Saturday evening, 23rd Jan., I pursued the prisoner Jones—after taking him, I found, in coming back in the footsteps we ran, one fowl—it was shown to Kendall, and he claimed it.
JAMES BROWN (police-constable P 147.) On that Saturday evening I found two fowls in the track in which Jones ran—they were warm, and one was bleeding—they were shown to Kendall—he claimed them.
WILLIAM MORTON (police-sergeant P 7.) I had some conversation with

Jones, and went to Lambert's house on the morning of the 24th Jan.—I knew before that where he lived—he was not at home—I searched, and in bonnet-box in a chamber, I found a fowl which was picked—I found Heritage the same day—I told him he was charged with Boxall with stealing he fowls—he said, "I know nothing about Boxall or the fowls"—his father, who was present, said, "I have advised you several times to keep out of that gabond's company"—Heritage said, "I am all right"—in taking him along, he said, "It is that b—y Boxall—I have pretty well kept him ever since he has been out of prison—if be gets over this, I will give him some
thing he won't get over—he has led me astray two or three times, but I will lead him astray this time, I will tell the whole truth, on the Monday after
wards I saw the three prisoners together—I repeated, in presence of Heritage, hat Jones had said to me—Jones was asked if it was correct, and he nodded to it—I told Heritage that Jones stated he was with him at the time the policeman saw him in the Kent-road, that he had two cocks strung round him, and Jones had three, and he was to go to John Lambert's, is the Kent-road, who would be sure to take them—I then told Lambert what Jones had said about him—he said he knew nothing of either of them—that he was going to Brown's-fields on Saturday night, and he kicked against the fowl, which I found in the bonnet-box.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen Heritage before? A. I may have been him—I have no knowledge of him.

GEORGE LEADBEATER . I am an ostler—I reside in King's Reach-walk—I know the prisoners. On Saturday, 23rd Jan., I saw Boxall and Heritage in Rye-lane, Peckham, at four o'clock—I heard Heritage ask Boxall if he would go with him—Heritage said, "If we get anything to-night we will take it to Johnny's"—Boxall said no, he was afraid—Heritage then asked me if I would go—he did not say where, nor what it was for.

MARY BOXALL . I am the mother of the prisoner Boxall—he lives with me and my husband. On Saturday evening, 23rd Jan., he was at home be
tween three and four o'clock, and took tea with me—he went away, and I never saw him any more till he was in custody on the Monday—I know Heritage by sight—I have seen him come to my son—on that Saturday night he came about eight o'clock, and he asked for Dick—I said, "I am sure I don't know where he is Jack—I have not seen him since between three and four, I was wondering what had become of him"—he said, "Good-night," and went away.
HERITAGE,
LAMBERT,
NOT GUILTY .

640.
JOHN BONEL was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign; the money of
George Stevens, his master.

GEORGE STEVENS . I am a carrier out of Kent. I put up at the Spur Inn, in the Borough—I have been in the habit of employing the prisoner at different times for the last four or five years. On the 28th of Dec. I gave him a sovereign to go to Bishopsgate after a bag of shot, and to call at Mr. Ruff's for some bacon—he returned to more till he was apprehended.
Prisoner's Defence. I lost it; that is all I have to say.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

641.
THOMAS REDFORD was indicted
for stealing part of a brass lamp, value 4s.; part of one other lamp, 1s.; 2 cap girtings, 2d.; 1 drip cap, 2d.; 2 nozzles, 4d.; 1 metal ring, 2d.; the goods of
Elizabeth Young, his mistress: 2nd COUNT, stating it to be 3lbs. of brass; to which he pleaded

642.
ELIZABETH BAKER alias Bennett
and
HENRY GERHARD were indicted for
conspiracy.

WILLIAM BURBIDGE . I live in Bridge-street, Southwark, and conduct the business of my late father, for his executors—Thomas Keene is one, and there are others—it is a wholesale hat and cap manufactory—about the 9th of Nov. the prisoner Gerhard came to the shop—he said he was going to open a shop at the Triangle, Kennington Cross, and wanted a few hats and other things—he selected about 40l. worth—I asked him for a reference, and he gave me one to a Mr. Maymott, No. 13. Charles-street, Northampton-square—I either wrote or caused a letter to be written to Mr. Maymott, and received an answer—I took the answer to Mr. Maymott, to know if it was his hand-writing—he said it was—after having received this letter, and seen Maymott myself on the subject, I permitted Gerhard to have ten or twelve dozens of hats, on the 14th of Nov., amounting to 40l. some odd shillings, and on the 16th of Nov. I sent him good to the amount of 11l. 4s. 9d.—I went to the shop about a month afterwards, and saw the goods—I went to the shop again shortly after Christmas, found it shut up, and no one on the premises—when Gerhard came to me he had whiskers and no mustachios—I have never been paid a farthing.
COURT. Q. In what state was the shop when you went there within a month? A. It had goods in it, though I do not think there was anything like the quantity we sent.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. It was opened as a hat shop? A. Yes—I think there was nothing but hats had caps—it was after Christmas I saw it shut up—I was aware some goods had been seized for rent—I took a guarantee from Maymott—I was satisfied with it, or I should not have let the goods go—it is not unusual for persons who give a reference to get goods.

THOMAS COTTER . I am clerk and warehouseman to Messrs. Keene and Co. On the 14th of Nov. I gave some goods out to be taken to Gerhard's shop, at Kennington Cross, and on the 16th I gave some more to be taken to the same place—here are a dozen of those hats here—on the 9th of Jan., from information, I went to Mara-place, Old Kent-road—I there saw twenty hats—I went on the Tuesday following with Serjeant Archer, and took pos
session of them—they were in the care of Mr. Gilmore.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. You did not see either of the pri
soners at the Kent-road? A. No—I saw Gerhard but once, when he first came to me to buy the hats, and we received a letter on the 17th or 18th of Dec., requiring 20l. worth more, saying, that having expended all his money in hosiery, he could not pay for them just then, and we declined to send them.

JAMES CHAMBERS . I am carman to messrs. Keene and Co. I delivered these goods at the Triangle, one parcel on the 14th and the other on the 16th—the prisoner Gerhard signed my tickets—he had no mustachios then, but he had whiskers which he has not now.

RACHAEL COHEN . I live in Ann's-place, Whitechapel—I deal in fur and caps—I have known Gerhard eighteen or nineteen months—his wife is my cousin—I know a man who goes by the name of Maymott; his name is Walker, I have known him as long as I have Gerhard; they are friends—I

know Baker by the name of Bennett—I have seen Maymott and Gerhard together; I have not seen Baker with them—just before Christmas I went to Gerhard's shop at the Triangle—Gerhard was not at home—Maymott called in—he asked if Mr. Gerhard was within—Mr. Gerhard said, "No," and asked what he wanted—he said he wanted Mr. Gerhard to go to Mr. Burbidge for more hats—Mr. Gerhard said, "No, he sha'n't go for any more"—Maymott said he should go, because Burbidge was very sweet—three days after I went to the house again—I saw Gerhard there, and Maymott was there with him—there were not so many hats there then as there were the first time I went—Icannot say how often I went to the shop altogether—I went several times—I mostly found Maymott there—on one occasion, (a month before Christmas,) I heard Maymott tell Gerhard that he had sold part of the hats to Levy—on another occasion I heard Mr. Gerhard ask her hus
band what he had done with the hats—he said he had sold them—I heard Mr. Gerhard say that Mr. Bennett had been one reference, and Maymott (that was Walker) was the other—she said Mr. Bennett was to have some of the hats, but she would not have them when they wanted her to have them.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Do you know a person who goes by the name of Ann Jones? A. No—I never went by that name myself in my life, nor by the name of Mr. Nye—I am a Jewess—I do not live with my husband—I had one child by my husband, which I can prove by my vestry—I went before the vestry just before I had that child—I did not swear before the High priest that I was not with child; certainly not—I have lived with nobody but my mother since I lived with my husband.

JAMES GILMORE . I live at No. 4, Maria-place, Old Kent-road. On Tuesday, the 12th of Jan., I delivered up the hats, in twenty hat-boxes, to the policeman and the witness—they are now in Court—these boxes contain hats and caps—I am a broker—I received them about the 27th of Dec., from Mr. Gerhard—he brought them with several other things for sale—there were two other persons with him when he came—there was a van load of fixtures, a counter, shelves, chairs, tables, and other things—I did not know they were coming at that time—I knew they were coming, for Gerhard had applied to me to buy them—he said he had been in business, and could not make it answer, or something of that kind—I did not know the parties who came with him, but he said to one man, "Sparks, hand down that counter?"—I bought the things of him, and gave him 4l. 4s. for them—I did not buy the hats—I do not deal in hats—Gerhard said he would send for them again—in the meantime I received a warrant from the landlord for the rent, and I de
tained them—I delivered them up to the policeman.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. You knew of his opening this shop? A. Yes—I have known him these two years—I always understood him to be a seafaring man—he has been so till within the last three years—I did not consider he was adapted for business at all, and was not surprised to hear the business did not answer—I am sure eight persons out of ten do not succeed when they begin with a small capital—I never thought him a wealthy man—when I first knew him he had whiskers, but no mustachios.
JURY. Q. Was the shop fitted up as a hat shop? A. Yes—it was those fittings he brought to me.
COURT. Q. Did the prisoner fit it up? A. He told me he fitted it up.

JOHN ARCHER (police-sergeant G 8.) I accompanied Cotter to Mr. Gil
more's house—I found twenty-three hat boxes and twenty-two hats, and some caps in them—I took Mr. Baker into custody on the 20th of Dec., at No. 22 Bartlett's-buildings, Holborn—I found there twelve hats and four caps—I

knocked at the door—two women got up at the window, and refused to let us in—we staid there a quarter of an hour, and then a person got over the railings, got in at the kitchen window, and let us in—I met Mr. Baker com
ing down the stairs, she slipped from me, and ran to the water-closet—I caught her there, and found in her hand this pocked-book, which she was putting down the pipe of the water-closet—these hats have been shown to Mr. Burbidge, who identified them, and the caps have been shown to Mr. Krotouski, who identified them.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You found these hats in a room in which Baker was not? A. Yes—there was no one in the house but her and another women—it is a large house—they told me Mr. Sparks had taken it, but I waited all night, and he did not come—he has not been seen since—I did not except he would come and take the hats from me—I rather thought he would not—he is one of the gang.

HENRY DUBOIS (police-sergeant N 14.) I have known Baker four years and two months, by the name of Bennett, and by numerous names—I know Walker—he goes by the name of Maymott—he did live at No. 13, Charles-street—I have known him to go by other names—I watched the house, and have seen Baker go there—I know Gerhard—I do not know that he opened a shop; only from hearsay—I never saw him go to No. 13, Charles-street—I have seen him in company with Maymott—I have been watching them when they have not seen me.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Was it Baker or her sister you saw going to Maymott's? A. Herself—I know her well—I have been watching them for years—I have known her and her husband the last two years and a half—her husband's name is Francis Bennett—he is now in Whitecross-street prison—at least he was a little while ago—he was arrested on the 17th of June, by a timber-merchant—I have seen him in Whitecross-street.

THOMAS JAMES TASKER . I live at No. 46, Great Dover-street, in the Borough. I am a manufacture of stocks, collars, and braces—about the 10th or 12th of Dec. Gerhard called at my shop—he said he was a hatter, living at No. 4, Kennington-cross, and he wished to add to his business stocks, collars, and braces—I showed him several—he asked me my terms, and I told him, that he being a stranger, I should expect him to pay me cash for the first parcel, which he said he could not do, having spent 70l. in fitting out his shop, and the hats he had bought he had paid ready money for—I asked him who he bought them of—he mentioned some name which I do not recollect—after some conversion he gave me a reference to a man named Collins, No. 43, Canterbury-street, York-road, Lambeth—I inquired about that reference, and, in consequence of what I heard, I objected to it—I men
tioned to Gerhard that I was dissatisfied—he then referred me to Mr. Charles Maymott, No. 13, Charles-street, Northampton-square—I went there, and Saw him—I asked if he knew a man named Gerhard, in business at Ken
nington-cross; he said yes, he had known him some years—he said he was a respectable man; that his mother was a person of independent property, and that his wife also had an annuity—I asked if he would become security for him to the amount of 30l.—he hesitated at first, and then he said 30l. was not much object to him, as he was a retired tradesman, having been in some business as a manufacturer of some article connected with chronometers, but what I cannot recollect—he agreed to give me security—I told him I should not be satisfied unless he would accept a bill to become due in a months from the date of the invoice, and I should not let the goods go till I had the bill—I

sent him a bill to that purport, and Gerhard brought me the bill accepted—this is it—on the 18th of Dec. I sent Gerhard a portion of the goods, and some more afterwards—these are the two invoices—the amount altogether is 22l. 4s.—I went to the house, at the Triangle, a few days after Christmas—I found the shop was shut up, and no one in it—I went through the form of presenting the bill of exchange at Maymott's house, because I thought I might be asked some questions about it—I found the house shut up—I have not received a farthing.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Did you go to Gerhard's shop? A. Yes—it was fitted up as a hat and cap-maker's—he told me he had paid 70l. for the fixtures and the house together—I had not known the house be
fore—I have not seen any of the stocks and other things since—I do not know whether a fiat of bankruptcy was issued against Maymott.

BENJAMIN KROTOUSKI . I am of the firm of Brown and Krotouski, of London-wall; we are wholesale cap-manufacturers. These four caps, found at Baker's, in Bartlett's-buildings, and these twenty caps, found at Mr. Gil
more's, are my property—I sold them to Gerhard on the 19th of Nov.—I sold him caps to the amount of 11l. 15s.—I required a reference from him, and he referred me to Mr. Baker, No. 51, Herbert-street, New North-road—I sent a servant there—I afterwards got a guarantee—I have received 3l. on account.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Have you not said that if you had not had such a good reference you would not have sent the goods? A. I did not say so—I did not want to trust him till I had a reference.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. You did not know that Mr. Baker had been in the Debtors'-prison? A. No.

JEREMIAH SIMMONDS . I am a hat manufacturer, and live in Union-street, Borough. In Nov. last Gerhard called on me—he wanted some goods—he gave me a reference to Mr. Baker, No. 51, Herbert-street, New North-road—Gerhard told me he (Baker) was a retired laceman—I went to No. 51, Herbert-street—I was asked into the parlour, and after I had been there some time, the prisoner Baker came in—she asked what my business might be—I told her I came in reference to a person named Gerhard, who had called on me and wanted some goods—I should have said that in the first place I asked for Mr. Baker—she said Mr. Baker was out, but perhaps she might do as well—she said Gerhard was respectably connected, he was a very respectable young man, and what goods I let him have were quite as safe as if I kept them in my own possession—that his mother was a person of independent property, and he would come into possession of 800l. very shortly, and he did not wish to trouble his friends for anything for the purpose of opening this business—I heard something afterwards, and refused to supply my goods.

HENRY DUBOIS
re-examined. Q. Did you ever say you knew where Baker was in Nov.? A. I do not know Baker—I know Bennett—he was in White
cross-street prison in Nov.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. When did he leave there? A. I do not believe he has left yet—he was to be there for six months after he was brought up for the last hearing—he went there on the 17th of June—I went to the prison in Nov.—I cannot state any particular day that I went there—I have been there and seen the prisoner Baker come to see him—I have not been there in Dec.—I cannot be sure that I saw him there in Nov.—I have been there since Dec., and did not see him.
JOHN CHERRY . I am a carman, and live in Goswell-street. On the 24th

of Dec. I removed some goods from No. 51, Herbert-street, New North-road, to No. 22, Bartlett's-building—I went to Herbert-street about a quarter-past six o'clock in the morning—I found the prisoner Baker there—I removed furniture out of the house, and large cases or boxes—I had a van and a cart and filled them both—I took all the things to No. 22, Bartlett's-buildings—I found Mr. Baker there ready to receive them.

GERHARD—
GUILTY .
Confined One Year.

BAKER—
GUILTY .
Confined Nine Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 1ST OF MARCH, 1847.
